entry.et: perhaps from Middle Low German lasich feeble; akin to Middle High German erleswen to become weak

def.dt: :disinclined to activity or exertion :not energetic or vigorous
:encouraging inactivity or indolence a lazy summer day
:droopy lax a rabbit with lazy ears
:placed on its side lazy E livestock brand

entry.pt: lazy indolent slothful mean not easily aroused to activity. lazy suggests a disinclination to work or to take trouble take-out foods for lazy cooks. indolent suggests a love of ease and a dislike of movement or activity the heat made us indolent. slothful implies a temperamental inability to act promptly or speedily when action or speed is called for fired for being slothful about filling orders.

def.dt: :a revolving tray used for serving food, condiments, or relishes
:a series of jointed and pivoted bars capable of great extension used to pick up or handle something at a distance
